news.title: Word of the Day
news.description:
Tax Expenses
Tax expenses refer to the amount of tax that a company is liable to pay.
It is categorised into current tax (taxes to be paid for the current accounting period) and deferred tax (income taxes payable in future).
In the income statement of a company, tax expenses are deducted from the profit to calculate the net profit.

news.title: 6 Day Course
news.description:
Theme: tax-saver mutual funds
Day 5: Friday
ELSS funds are required to invest more than 80% of their money in equity (share markets).
But, there is no rule mandating the percentage of the money that needs to be invested in large-cap, mid-cap, and small-cap stocks.
Still, most ELSS funds invest a bulk of their money in large-cap stocks. Smaller portions are invested in mid and small-cap stocks.
These are all actively managed funds.
SEBI has just given the permission for passive ELSS funds. This would mean the ELSS funds invest in an index. No fund manager makes the buy/sell decision.
Regardless, the main motive of ELSS funds remains the same: generate higher returns while saving tax.

news.title: Featured Question
news.description:
"Why there is share price variations in BSE & NSE?"
Any share’s price is determined by supply and demand.
On both exchanges, BSE and NSE, trading is happening at the same time — causing the prices to go up and down.
It is possible that a stock climbs/falls more on one exchange. This happens because of a difference in supply and demand on the different exchanges.
There could be more buyers on one exchange and more sellers on another exchange.
This is why there is a difference.
But do note, most of the time, the prices are either the same or very similar.
Why?
Because if the stock is priced lower on one exchange, people start buying from it and selling at the exchange where the price is higher — for a profit.
This causes the difference in prices to become very small or vanish.
